title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 30 [may 1869]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 30 [May 1869]
text: M 30 evening My dear Waltall alonei receives your kind letter this morning i was glad to hear from you glad you had a good visit i was fearful you didentdidn't have quite as good a time as i wanted you to have we cantcan't be quite as free to talk when any one is present as if we were alone) but if the visit done peter good it didentdidn't doodo us any particular harm) well walt as you say sometimes in your letters things goes on about the same with me as usual only i have been rather lamer than usuali beleevebelieve i am worse when i stay in all the time than when i go out i beleivebelieve i shall try to go out to morrowtomorrow if itsit's pleasant i feel the need of going out a little i thought i would not be away if mr Oconor should call but he has not so i think he has returned to washingtonWashington)walter dear you needentneedn't send me harpers as i procured it the other nighthellen price was here and spent the day or it was rather late when she came nearly noon but she staidstayed till nearly evening last saturdaySaturday Emily is married about two or three weeks ago they board with mrs price but are going to houskeeping mrs price has not been well but has got better except a coughfcough ellen had a letter from Clapp wishing to know if you was in washingtonWashington as there was nobody out of his own family that he thought so much of as you that he had written to you but had got no answer he has been to new york and put up at lessey farlands i believe thatsthat's name and she gave him clothsclothes to make him desentdecent and there has been a collection to get him paper and materials to write hellen said he was tipseytipsy nearly all the time he was in new yorkNew York he wrote to hellen she had the letter here he was never so glad to get back out of new yorkNew York that all was changed) george will be home next saturdaySaturday i expect Jeff and all are about the samegood bie walter dear Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 30 [May 1869]
